participants.participant: Robert Le Blanc, Group Financial Risk Director

plist.p: Morning, everybody. Welcome to this presentation of our 2008 results. You're all very welcome. We've heard that there's been some disruption in the City, at one of the tube stations, so a number of people may be joining us late. So we will see.

Anyway, I'm sure that all of you will have seen the open letter, which John Varley and I wrote, and sent out a couple of weeks ago. And in that letter, we've talked amongst other things, about the fact that we were changing the date of this presentation. So I'm very grateful to all of you for managing to accommodate the change in the schedule.

Now this morning, we're going to have three presentations, two as usual are going to be by Chris Lucas and by John Varley, but the third is, the third presenter -- third presentation is new, and it's going to be by Robert Le Blanc, who is well-known to some, but not to all of you. Robert is our Group Risk Director and he's going to cover the field of risk management and our risk portfolios. And in doing so, he is going to draw on a number of the key disclosures that we have made in our results this morning.

The consequence of all this is that, the running time for the presentations will be a little longer than usual. But there will be a plenty of time at the end for questions in the normal way. And of course as well as the three presenters, there will also be Bob Diamond and Frits Seegers available to answer questions too.

Just to help you not to scribble down everything that we put, and say as it comes out, I should say that all of the presentations and the accompanying slides will be released in full, on our website as soon as John has finished his presentation.
So with no more ado, can I please ask you as usual to switch-off your mobiles phones and your Blackberries. And let's get on with the first presentation, which is Chris.

Good morning, and thank you, Marcus. We've delivered profit before tax of just over £6 billion in 2008; this includes gains from acquisitions of £2.4 billion, profits from non-core disposals of £0.6 billion, and gross credit market losses of £8.1 billion, which were partially offset by gains on owned credit of £1.7 billion. As you all know, 2008 was an extremely challenging year, but despite that, we've taken opportunities to progress our strategy.

In Retail and Commercial Banking, we've continued to expand the business profitability. In Investment Banking, we've taken a significant step with the acquisition of Lehman Brothers in North America. And we've also raised over £13.6 billion of new Tier-1 capital for the Group.

Turning to Group performance in more detail, the income increased slightly despite absorbing significant credit market losses. Cost increased 9% to £14.4 billion and impairment almost doubled. Our effective tax rate was 13% in 2008, this compares to 28% in '07 and the reduction results from offsetting the Lehman's acquisition gain, against Barclays' historical tax losses in the U.S. All this has generated earnings per share of 59 pence and a return on equity of 16.5%.

I know you are all interested in the balance sheet and our capital position, and I'll talk about these later. But before I do that, I'm going to run through in performance by division, starting with Global Retail and Commercial Banking, where profits were up 6% to £4.4 billion.

Profits in UK Retail Banking were up 7% to £1.4 billion. The income grew 4%, benefiting from a strong performance the mortgages and the current accounts. We've continued to be substantial providers in the mortgage market. Our balances increased 18% to just over £82 billion, and our market share of net new lending was 36%.

Our risk profile remained conservative. Even after market falls, the average loan to value of our total mortgage book, including buy-to-let was 40% in '08 compared to 34% in '07. On new lending, the average loan to value was 47%. This business was written at good spreads and the overall asset margin increased slightly.

On the deposit side, balances increased 3% to £90 billion and the liabilities margin declined slightly to just over 2%, showing the first impact as sharp reductions in base rates towards the end of the year.

Cost in UK Retail Banking increased 2% as we reinvested efficiency gains back into the business. We've launched a range of new products during the year, both in current accounts and savings. And over the last three years, we've completed over 670 branch refurbishments, which is about 40% of the network.

The cost income ratio improved one percentage point to 56% and impairment grew 8% to £600 million, and mortgage impairment within that remained low at £24 million. In Barclays Commercial Bank, profits declined 7% to just under £1.3 billion. Income grew 7%, driven by increased sales of treasury products including foreign exchange and interest rate derivatives.

Loans and advances grew 14% to over £80 billion with strong growth in term loans. Customer accounts and deposit margins were broadly stable. Cost growth of 14% included lower gains on the sale of property, increased investments in payments infrastructure and growth in the operating lease business.

Impairment charges increased 42% to £414 million. The biggest single charge we took in Commercial Banking was £40 million and we've benefited from our cautious stance on leveraged finance, property and construction lending. Robert Le Blanc will talk more about this later.

At Barclaycard profits grew 31% to just under £800 million, as a result of strong growth in international cards, and a £40 million contribution from the acquisition of Goldfish. Barclaycard International profits grew by over 70% to £260 million, which is about one-third of the total Barclaycard profits. The largest international business is Barclaycard US, where profits of $249 million were well above our acquisition plan for '08 of $150 million.

Income increased 27%, broadly in line with the rate of cost growth both were driven by Barclaycard International and the first time contribution of Goldfish. A gain of £80 million from the sale of shares in Visa and MasterCard also contributed to income growth. We wrote-off £37 million in goodwill related to FirstPlus, which we closed to new business in August.

Impairment charges increased 33% driven mainly by Barclaycard US, where we saw book growth and increasing delinquency rates. 68 million resulted from the inclusion of Goldfish, which was partially offset by lower impairment in the other UK businesses. This reduction is a result of actions we've taken to the book in recent years.

Moving to Western Europe, profits grew 31% to £260 million. This included £82 million of gains from Visa or MasterCard and a £52 million gain from the acquisition of an Italian mortgage business. We used these gains to continue to expand our European business. And costs increased 38%, and we added almost 350 new distribution points in France, Italy, Spain, and Portugal bringing the total number to 1,150.

The pace of business growth has contributed to income growth of 53% with customer assets and liabilities are up more than 50% as a result of both customer inflows and changes in the sterling/euro exchange rates.

There was a steep increase in impairment charges to £300 million, most of which arose from a deteriorating credit conditions and rising delinquencies in Spain. This included £82 million in the Spanish property sector and £66 million in Spanish cards. The impairment charges increased from a low base. And we are now at about 55 basis points at a percentage of loans and advances.

Emerging markets grew profits by 34% to £134 million, this included £82 million from Visa or MasterCard. Once again, we've used these – the gains to expand the business. We've done this both in the existing markets including Africa, the UAE and India and in new markets with the acquisition of Expobank in Russia, Bank Akita in Indonesia and a banking license in Pakistan. The number of distribution points increased by almost 300 to 840.

Income grew more than costs at 80%, driven by very strong growth in customer assets and liabilities. Impairment charges grew sharply to £166 million as a result of the rapid pace of book growth, a maturing portfolio and increased delinquencies.

Absa Group Limited announced profit growth of 8% in rand this morning, against a backdrop of weakening economic growth, rising interest rates, and a consumer downturn in South Africa. GRCB Absa, which excludes Absa Capital and Absa Cards, reported sterling profits of just over £550 million, which is down 8% year-on-year, reflecting a 7% average devaluation of the rand. Income growth of 10%, which included £47 million from the Visa IPO, was driven by higher assets and liability balances.

Costs grew 3%, well below the rate of inflation in South Africa. We've increased the number of distribution points by 180 to about 1,200 and the cost income ratio improved four percentage points to 59%.

There was a steep increase in impairment charges to almost £350 million in a difficult environment for customers. This was largely the result of increased delinquencies in the mortgage book, the overall impairment charges as a percentage of loans and advances was just over 100 basis points.

Moving onto Investment Banking and Investment Management, I'll start with Barclays Capital where we recorded a profit of £1.3 billion, including a gain from the acquisition of Lehman Brothers of 2.3 billion, gains on owned credit of £1.7 billion and gross credit market losses of £8.1 billion.

The acquisition gain was larger than we originally indicated, because IFRS requires us to recognize intangible assets, such as intellectual property and the value of the franchise. This amounted to £900 million. And in addition, we've incurred integration and investment costs through the P&L of about £200 million. The integration was completed successfully in January, and we've – and it has contributed to a very strong net income growth in the United States.

Excluding credit market writedowns, total income of Barclays Capital increased 6%. We've continued to benefit from diversification, with good income contributions from interest rates, currency products, emerging markets, prime services and commodities.

Costs fell a net 5%. Bear in mind that this includes £200 million of acquisition cost, three months of Lehman's run rate cost, and the impact of sterling weakness. These were more than offset by reductions in performance-related pay, discretionary investment and the use of short-term contractors. Headcount increased by nearly 7,000 to just over 23,000 driven by the Lehman's acquisition.

We've given substantial additional disclosure on our credit market exposures this morning, and as you'd expect, these numbers have been subject to scrutiny by independent auditors. We incurred gross credit market losses of £8.1 billion, partly offset by gains on owned credits of £1.7 billion and hedging of net attributable income of £1.4 billion. Net credit market losses were £5 billion.

We've accounted for and valued our exposures consistently throughout the year. And these now include £1.1 billion of securities acquired from Lehman's. Reported values reflect the substantial fall in sterling versus the dollar, as well as decreases in the fair value of assets wrapped by monolines. Net sales and pay-downs have reduced these balances by £9.4 billion during the year. Where we sold assets, we've done so at prices consistent with our marks.

At Barclays Global Investors, profits decreased 19% to £595 million, as we provided £260 million of support for selective liquidity products. Income declined 4% to 1.8 million -- sorry -- £1.8 billion, as incentive and management fees were impacted by declining asset values. Reduced asset values also impacted assets under management, which went down to $1.5 trillion. Market forces were partially offset by net new asset inflows of $99 billion, largely in the iShares business.

In Sterling, assets under management were stable as net new assets and exchange rates offset adverse market movements. Excluding support for liquidity funds, costs of BGI were down 11%. At Barclays Wealth, profits of £670 million included a gain on the disposal of the closed life business of £330 million. Excluding that gain, profits rose 12%. Income grew 3%, driven by a strong growth in customer deposits and lending, which were both up over 20%.

Total client assets increased 10% to £145 billion, reflecting net new asset inflows and the acquisition of Lehman's Private Investment Management business. The growth was partially offset by the impact of market movements and the sale of the closed life business.

This slide gives a breakdown of costs, which grew 9%, or £1.2 billion, during the year. The major movements can be broken down into three groups. Firstly, there are increases over £500 million on '07, which include £165 million in head office costs, arising from our contribution to the UK Financial Services compensation scheme and a review of compliance with U.S. sanctions, as well as £220 million of incremental non-cash charges from writing off goodwill and from higher amortization of intangible assets. This also includes gains on property sales, which were £120 million lower than 2007.

Secondly, strategic investment in the business accounted for over £1 billion, including £600 million deployed in Western Europe and emerging markets to expand our distribution network, £180 million of additional support from liquidity funds in BGI, and £285 million, including the restructuring and investment costs from all acquisitions, including Lehman's.

Finally, set against these increases, we've made a significant reduction in variable costs across the Group, and in particular in Investment Banking and Investment Management. Headcount across the Group increased 16%, while total staff costs were down 7%.

Turning to the Group balance sheet. Our assets and liability totals have grown significantly during the year. Changes in currency rates have been an important contributor, with sterling down 31% against the euro, and 37% and against the dollar. In Barclays Capital alone, this increased asset values by over £140 billion.

When we look at the balance sheet, we distinguish changes from the -- that alter the consumption of cash, capital, and risk from those that don't. This slide sets out the nominal growth in our balance sheet of £830 billion year-on-year. Of this, almost £740 billion arises from increased derivatives balances.

Loans and advances grew by £124 billion and other balance sheet assets went down by £35 billion. The last two categories include £36 billion of new assets from acquisitions, as well as the impact of substantial foreign exchange movements.

The increase in derivatives balances is driven by a higher volatility in indices, interest rates and other valuation parameters. Most of these balances represent receivables and payables with the same counterparties. They are subject to enforceable netting agreements recognized by U.S. GAAP; and under U.S. GAAP, the balance sheet is £900 billion smaller.

If we consider tangible balance sheet leverage, excluding accounting impacts on derivatives, assets under management, and settlement balances, adjusted gross leverage has improved from 33 times Tier-1 capital at the end of '07 to 28 times at the end of '08. This reflects the issuance of capital and an increase in retained earnings over the course of the year.

We expect gross leverage to improve to about 24 times on an adjusted basis of Tier-1 capital, as more of our mandatory convertible notes and reserve capital instruments qualify as Tier-1 capital. Over time, we'd expect that 24 times to reduce further.

We significantly increased our capital during the year, as you know. Shareholders equity increased from £23 billion at the end of '07 to £37 billion at the end of '08. We've raised £5 billion in ordinary equity and more than £4 billion through the issue of mandatory convertible notes and warrants.

Attributable profit was £4.4 billion, and we've paid dividends of £2.3 billion. Risk weighted assets increased £80 billion to over £430 billion, 60 billion of this was driven by exchange rate movements, and the balance represents the additional pro-cyclical effect of Basel II. Our capital ratios on a pro forma basis at the end of the year were 6.7% for equity -- sorry-- 9.7% for Tier-1 and 6.7% for equity Tier-1.

Looking forward, we expect 2009 to be another challenging year. Low interest rates are likely to continue and this will reflect the liability margin. So, we'll also receive some benefit from our structural interest rate hedge. We expect RWA growth in single digits and capital ratios well in excess of the minimum levels set by the FSA.

So to conclude, it's been an extremely challenging year and a busy one. We've raised over £13 billion of new Tier-1 capital for the Group. We took a very significant step with the acquisition of Lehman's in North America. And we've continued to expand our retail and Commercial Banking business profitably.
Thanks very much. I'm now going to handover to Robert, to talk about the impairment trends in 2008, and our expectations for 2009.

Thank you, Chris. Good morning. I want to cover a lot of territory looking across these topics. I'll start with an update on credit market exposures for Barclays Capital, including the valuation process we use and a brief look at each of our different credit books.

Then a review of how we've managed our major credit portfolios in Global, Retail and Commercial Banking, covering the UK Retail portfolio, our UK and U.S. Cards business, The UK Commercial Bank; and then Absa, Spain and emerging markets.

And after that, I'll look at market risk. I'll do all this to give you a clear view of how the current portfolios developed, but the important part of our job is to look forward. So I'll end by covering the wider economic environment and our impairment outlook for 2009.

Before I cover the credit market exposures, let me explain our governance fair valuations and impairment calculations. Starting with the valuation process, the very important point is that most of our credit market exposures use fair values taken directly from the market.

During 2008, we disposed of more than £9 billion of assets through sales and paydowns. These sales were at or near our valuations and they included for example, disposals of whole loans, commercial property loans and Alt-A securities.

Risk management is an independent function in Barclays and I'm responsible for signing-off our impairment charges. They're brought to our Board Audit Committee for review before the Board signs off our results, and they are of course reviewed by our external auditors. We use a model to calculate impairment for our ABS CDOs, which is the correct approach.

Let me explain how we do that, so you can understand the process and see why a read across from bank-to-bank normally won't work. This graph shows the delinquency trend for subprime assets originated in 2004. As a first step, we use industry data up to the present and this is recent data from S&P for illustration.

As a second step, we apply a loss severity, which tells us how much we would lose in the event of a default. This two-step approach produces a loss rate, which in this case, is half the default rate. Then we look forward to forecast the loss rate in the future. We use this process for other years to produce loss rates for different vintages, and we've extrapolated the S&P data to illustrate this.

The later vintages of '06 and '07 have higher delinquency rates leading to a higher loss rates. And this is important because almost three quarters of our ABS CDO assets are from 2005 or earlier, which is why they have lower loss rates. That's basically how it works. Although, we look at many other factors such as regional differences, cash flow timing, repayment rates and others.

In summary then, our valuation process has four key features. First, most assets use fair values taken from the market. Second, the impairment model we have is widely used in the industry, and the inputs are from the market. They are not just our assumptions.

Third, the models are forward-looking. And fourth, they clearly differentiate between assets, in this example by vintage. Putting all these factors together explains how we come to appropriate impairment reserves.

Now let me get into our credit market exposures. During 2008, our exposures in ABS CDOs fell by about half in dollar terms, from liquidations, and from £1.5 billion of losses on that book. We took some important actions that drove exposures down when we triggered unwind clauses and liquidated two-thirds of our remaining structures. Those assets were then moved at fair value to our trading books.

As I explained a minute ago, valuations in the CDO book are influenced by vintage, and almost three quarters of the assets were originated in '05 or earlier. We have no CDO squared and following those liquidations we have no remaining mezzanine or synthetic CDO structures. Any second lien assets were already written-down to zero in 2007.

For the remaining RMBS assets, half of them are still AAA and AA, and about a quarter of the rest are investment grade. Other sub-prime exposures also declined by about half in dollar terms and Alt-A exposures were down by about a third. Of this, sub-prime whole loans fell by about half, and the remaining book is almost completely assets originated by EquiFirst.

In April, we qualified as an originator under the Federal Housing Administration program in the U.S. And that means, we can take suitable assets from our portfolios and submit them to the FHA for a guarantee. As a result, about half the remaining sub-prime whole loans are being submitted to the FHA for guarantees and we're selling them more easily and at the best prices.

Moving on to commercial mortgages, this includes loans and CMBS securities. Let me give you the breakdown. The LTVs at origination are shown here. Just over half of the loan portfolios in the U.S., about 20% in Germany, 7% is in the UK and the remainder is widely spread with only 1% in Spain.

In Dollar terms, the U.S. book reduced by almost 20% last year. Two large facilities in the U.S. make up about 40% of the book. They are based on a wide pool of properties and they paid down £800 million last year. These are fair value books and the average mark across the U.S. assets was 88%. The rest of the book is well-spread across about 75 names.

The loan book in Europe is well-diversified. And for almost all the book, we have the right to test the loans against covenant and LTV levels, and that allows us to renegotiate better terms and conditions.

Now, I'd like to review our monoline exposure. When I think about this, I focus on three factors. First, the underlying assets. Collateralized loan obligations are about two-thirds of the notional assets with monoline guarantees. These CLOs are made up of a pool of loans from about 2,000 U.S. and 600 European corporate borrowers.

Virtually, all of our CLO positions remain AAA or AA. And they have the huge benefit of a lot of junior debt beneath them in the capital structure. That's really important. Because it would take a corporate default rate of more than 20% across the whole loan book for many years before the cash flow to our CLO positions would be reduced.
Not surprisingly, for our assets, there have been no defaults and no missed payment on any to-date. For our other monoline assets, CMBS make up about 15%, and all of them are rated AAA of AA.

And finally, 10% of the assets are U.S. RMBS, where most of the ratings are sub-investment grade, but where all the payments to our assets are still being made. And this is where I look at the second factor and that's the guarantee provided by the monolines.

For the RMBS assets, virtually all of the cover is provided by monolines that remain investment grade. And remember, this cover is not to replace market value, it's insurance to replace any missing cash flow payments that might occur in the future. And that leads to the third factor, which is the methodology we use to calculate our reserves.

Given that exposure has arisen, two of the most important factors that drive these valuations are default probabilities and loss severities. Our default probabilities are forward-looking and much higher than their historic levels. Looking across the range, they are at or higher than the default probabilities we believe are implied by the current agency ratings.

For 60% of our monoline exposure, we further stress our probabilities beyond the current agency rating and our loss severity assumptions range from 45 to 100% depending on the monoline. So taking into account, our assets the nature of the monoline guarantees and the credit position of the monolines themselves, our total reserve for monoline exposure is £1.7 billion. We believe, other large international banks use a similar reserving methodology and from what we've have seen their results calibrate to our reserve levels.

Now, let's move to leveraged finance. Sponsored leveraged finance balances were reduced by £3.1 billion last month following the full repayment of Alltel exposure at par. These are drawn loans and therefore they are held in our banking book, which is the accounting treatment we've used for many years, and which is now being used more by other banks. Under this accounting treatment, an identified impairment charges taken only when a specific impairment event has occurred. So that's the accounting. Now let's look at the credit risk.

We have very few remaining undrawn facilities. And the portfolio performance continues to be satisfactory. Since the Alltel paydown, the U.S. book is small. The European portfolio is well spread by industry and region, however, 47% of the overall portfolio now relates to Alliance Boots & AA Saga.

Clearly, we have more of these loans than we had intended, but the credit performance of those companies continues on their original business plans. And I believe that the better banking decision is to retain these loans rather than force a sale into an unwilling market.

I've discussed some of loans in our portfolio; there have been a number of publicly known situations where loans are now in difficulty. We had the opportunity for a lead role on some of these which we declined.

I'm going to talk now about the performance of our major credit portfolios. And how we use and adjust risk appetite. A lot of banking is about risk management and we try to plan for the best by protect against the worst. So an important part of our job is to look forward to anticipate the dangers or the downside.

At the end of '07, when we were planning for '08 and '09, the market was still forecasting steady GDP – GDP -- pardon me, across the major economies, including the UK. After many years of growth these economies have several things in common; increasing residential and commercial property prices, high personal and corporate leverage and low unemployment. In particular, the unwinding of leverage led us to the view that we should prepare for a much weaker scenario going forward.

So our Executive Committee launched a formal program to give greater protection across all our credit portfolios in the UK, the U.S., Spain and South Africa. These included more than 300 immediate actions that had clear benefits and were fast to implement such as changes to lending criteria, to limits, and to collections.

We also decided to take more than 100 strategic actions. These were bigger decisions, such as giving up market share to get a better risk return balance, increasing hedging at a significant cost and being the first bank in South Africa to tighten our terms for mortgage lending.

In the fourth quarter of last year, we extended our program to emerging markets. The position of our books at the end of '07 was defensive, and the moves we've made last year help protect further against the continuing tough conditions.

Looking now at the portfolios, this slide shows the loss rates on loans and advances to customers. In the UK Retail Banking and UK Card portfolios these were either stable or slightly improved. The loan loss rate in Barclays Commercial Bank went up in '08 and that reflected an increase in impairment of £122 million. The increase in the BarCap impairment charge includes the 1.5 billion of impairment that I mentioned on the CDOs.

The remaining BarCap impairment charge of about £900 million was spread across a wide range of counterparties. And this includes any losses from corporates, financials, and the hedge fund unwinding that took place last year. The largest charge on any single loan in BarCap into 2008 was less than £50 million. I will now move into more detail on these books.

Looking at our individual portfolios, I will start with our UK Retail Bank mortgages. Chris said earlier, that the portfolio average loan-to-value is 40%. Importantly, only 10% of the book has an LTV above 85%. And we have not offered self-certified mortgages. We continue to support our customers, and for those in financial difficulty, we offer various options to help them including switching to interest only, term extensions, and arrangements to clear arrears.

Of our 725,000 residential mortgages, only about 6,000 are more than 90 days delinquent. We had less than 1% of the repossessions in the UK last year and less than 170 of our mortgages are currently in repossession. Our average LTV and buy-to-let is 56% and we have good income cover. And of our 50,000 buy-to-let mortgages, less than 500 are more than 90 days delinquent and only nine are in repossession.

Turning to UK Consumer Loans, balances have been steady during '08 and the book has shown a slightly reducing delinquency trend and a declining charge-off rate year-on-year. We've raised scorecard cutoff points, tightened affordability criteria, and scaled back the amount of available top-up lending.

Most importantly, more than 90% of our loan book is with existing Barclays customers. So we've been able to make lending decisions based on their previous track record. When I look at this portfolio, despite the good performance in '08, I expect the environment to move against these trends as we've recently seen.

Moving on to look at UK Cards, let's start by looking at the book in a different way. Each year, we measure the delinquency of new assets for that year three months after they come on the book. This delinquency rate for new vintages has been trending lower, showing that the credit quality of new lending has improved, which comes out in a way the book has been performing.

You'll remember that we reduced our book during '05 and '06. Since then, we've rebuilt balances mostly from the Goldfish acquisition, while applying tighter scorecard cut-offs, more selective balance growth, and more line decreases where appropriate.

Our approval rate for new cards remains at about 50%. Looking at charge-off rates, the industry rate has fluctuated. At the same time, our charge-off rate has declined, as a result of the improvement in our credit quality. Again although, we're not immune from current conditions, these portfolio characteristics give us some confidence that our UK card book is relatively well-positioned.

Now, let's move to our card business in the U.S. That was about 30% of overall impairment in Barclaycard last year. Our business in the U.S. is largely based on a partnership model, which provides us with good quality customers. For example, in 2008 we took over the loyalty credit card programs for U.S. Air and L.L. Bean.

In response, to the tougher consumer credit environment, we tightened qualification criteria and credit limits on new cards. We changed our score card models to reflect a stress, where unemployment could reach 10%. We removed $7 billion of limits through credit line decreases, and we stopped non-partnership open market acquisition.

Our delinquency rates were very low in 2006 because it was a new book. They've been increasing as the portfolio has matured, but remain below the industry average. I expect impairment to increase in '09, but the steps we've taken and the benefit of our partnership model should help mitigate against the current market conditions.

Turning to Barclays Commercial Bank, let me give you some context at how we look at risk here. For many years, our UK team has tracked the level of gearing across UK companies, because we have learned that when company gearing increases, corporate insolvency levels follow about two years later. When we removed the time lag like this, it's clear that they are very closely related.

During 2006, we saw that gearing was on the rise, as I'm showing you in the circle. So we took steps to protect our book. We tightened limits on lending to any one single borrower. We reduced limits or changed credit policy in those sectors we felt were most risky, such as commercial property and sponsored leverage lending. And we shifted the portfolio more towards secured lending.

From 2006, company gearing has increased and as predicted corporate insolvency has followed. This gave us an early view of the effects of increasing company gearing, and the changes we made from 2006 have helped to keep our losses at the low-end of the scale.

Let me explain how some of those measures have worked in practice. Chris mentioned that in 2008 the largest impairment charge against a single name in the Commercial Bank was £40 million. Because of the controls on single name exposure, the average of the next 10 losses was about £15 million.

In commercial property, we have only about £5 billion of investment and development lending. And the sector was about 5% of our limits. We have virtually no speculative development. We've done no equity underwriting and we have only £5 million of mezzanine debt. On balance, although overall impairment will increase, I don't expect commercial property lending to be an issue in 2009 for The Commercial Bank.

Looking ahead, the sponsored leveraged book will be under pressure this year. However, the average exposure is below £20 million. We have about a £100 million of mezzanine lending. And we would not expect any significant single loss. So although total limits were higher in '08, we've held to our sector limits.

I want to mention the other portfolios that we're watching carefully. First of all, Absa. There has been significant pressure on loan loss rates across retail portfolios driven by high interest rates on the back of persistent inflation and high customer leverage.

From June '06 to June '08, interest rates have risen by 500 basis points in South Africa. That would have made a monthly mortgage payment increase by about a third. As a consequence, mortgage loan loss rates increased from a low level of 30 basis points to a 100 basis points during the year. And delinquencies have risen in the consumer and vehicle finance portfolios.

The current LTV of the mortgage book has increased modestly from 38 to 41% during last year. During 2008, we took several important steps. We opened another collections call center, increasing collections staff from 850 to 1,400 and we reduced our LTVs for new mortgage business.

Looking ahead this year, asset growth will slow, house prices will fall and we expect average LTVs to rise from 41 to 45%. Retail impairment will continue to increase, although we've now seen 150 basis points of interest rate reductions since December and we may see a further 100 basis points cut in April, which will help customers.

Moving on to Western Europe. Our portfolio is mostly in Spain, and the deterioration in the Spanish property and construction sector during 2008 impacted our wholesale portfolios. We have property exposure in our medium and large business areas, but in lower proportions than the overall market.

We tightened our LTV criteria in 2007 and our policy during 2008 is to avoid new lending except where we could improve our overall position; for example, by obtaining security over a previously unsecured position.

We've also avoided participating in most of the large failed syndications and subsequent defaults in Spain that you will have read about in the press. Our largest single impairment in Spain in 2008 was just under £20 million.

Turning now to emerging markets. Our portfolios are growing quickly as we diversify and grow our earnings. The loan loss rate has risen and this has been driven by balance growth in the retail portfolios, particularly in India where we launched in 2007. Last year, we reduced our growth rate as we applied tighter lending criteria, and as we look ahead this year, we will keep a tight risk appetite in this area.
